title: Final Walk Through Before Closing: What Agents Need to Know
excerpt: Key Points Final walk through confirms the home’s condition before closing Check that all agreed repairs are complete Ensure the seller removed all personal items…
content:
Key Points

  • Final walk through confirms the home’s condition before closing
  • Check that all agreed repairs are complete
  • Ensure the seller removed all personal items
  • Make sure the condition hasn’t changed
  • Document any damage or last-minute issues
  • Final walk through generally happens 24–48 hours before close
  • Skipping it risks costly surprises after closing

Ah, the final walk through before closing—where you get one more shot to discover the seller’s idea of “move-in ready” means “oops, we took the fridge and the closet doors.” Think it’s just a formality? Around 1 in 20 final walk throughs uncover issues serious enough to kill the deal.

Whether it’s a light fixture swap-out that wasn’t in the deal or a surprise hole in the drywall, this isn’t the time to play it cool. A pre-closing walkthrough (or walk-through, or walkthrough—pick your preferred punctuation) is where buyers confirm that everything is still standing, functional, and as promised

So yeah, skipping it? Not recommended unless you enjoy filing complaints after you’ve already unpacked the moving truck. From who attends the final walk through to what to look for during it, we’re covering everything to help you nail this last step like the real estate pro you are. Here’s your handy dandy index:

What Is a Final Walk Through Before Closing?
Steps If You Find Issues During the Walkthrough

What Is a Final Walk Through Before Closing?

The final walk-through isn’t just a feel-good victory lap around the house. It’s your buyer’s last shot to make sure they’re not inheriting a leaky ceiling, a mysteriously absent stove, or “repairs” done with duct tape and hope. This is the moment to confirm that the property condition still matches the terms in the purchase agreement.

The goal? A clean and accurate property condition report, ideally without discovering a missing garage door or surprise pet damage. And if the home’s condition doesn’t match the contract, the buyer can hit the brakes faster than a bad credit score at underwriting.

Why the Final Walkthrough Actually Matters

This final check isn’t a chance to redecorate or get second thoughts on the paint color. It’s to confirm that repairs were done, nothing new is broken, and the seller didn’t swap your included appliances for something from 1992.

This is your buyer’s last shot at a property condition assessment before the keys change hands. If that fridge is gone or the AC stopped working—now’s the time to catch it. Not after closing, when it becomes your buyer’s expensive surprise.

When Does the Walkthrough Happen and Who Shows Up?

So when is the final walk through? Usually 24 to 48 hours before closing—right when everyone’s nerves are already fried. That gives just enough time to flag issues and maybe negotiate before the documents start flying.

Who attends the walkthrough? At a minimum the buyer and their real estate agent. Sometimes the seller tags along (usually awkwardly), and if the home’s older or had major repairs, bringing a home inspector can offer some extra peace of mind.

Depending on the size of the home, expect this step to take anywhere from a quick 15-minute breeze-through to a full hour-long real estate walkthrough. Pro tip: doing this in an empty house is much easier. You’ll spot damage, scuffs, and last-minute “oops” moments the seller left behind.

Setting the Right Expectations for the Buyer

Before stepping foot into the walkthrough, your buyer needs to know exactly what’s going down—and what’s definitely not. This isn’t the time to start spotting things they missed during the inspection and suddenly expect a new roof. The final walk through is a confirmation mission, not a second inspection with bonus drama.

Final Walkthrough vs. Home Inspection: Know the Difference

Let’s clear up the classic confusion: a home inspection happens early in the deal. That’s when buyers get the full diagnostic on the home—roof, foundation, outlets, ghost infestations, the works. Any problems found there? That’s when you negotiate repairs or concessions.

The final walk through, on the other hand, happens near the finish line. Think of it like a pre-delivery check. You’re there to make sure nothing’s changed since the deal was struck. It’s a verification step, not a redo of the inspection.

What the Final Walkthrough Is For:

Let’s keep it simple. The walkthrough before closing is for:
• Confirming agreed-upon repairs are actually done (no, sticky notes that say “FIX ME” don’t count)
• Ensuring the seller’s stuff is gone—not “mostly packed”
• Verifying everything that worked before still works now

What the Final Walkthrough Is Not For:

This is not your buyer’s chance to:
• Suddenly demand a full remodel
• Reopen negotiations because the wall color “hits different in daylight”
• Delay closing over stuff that should’ve been caught weeks ago

Make sure your buyer knows the rules of the final walkthrough checklist game. Because nothing kills a vibe—or a sale—like unrealistic expectations and last-minute finger-pointing. Clear expectations = smooth closing. You’re welcome.

Essential Final Walk Through Checklist (a.k.a. The “Let’s Not Regret This” List)

The final walk through before closing isn’t the time to wing it with good vibes and crossed fingers. Bring a real checklist and treat this like what it is—a last opportunity to make sure you’re not about to inherit someone else’s half-finished honey-do list. Snap pics of anything sketchy to back up your concerns and protect your buyer (and your commission).

Here’s what to check during your final walkthrough real estate adventure:

1. Verify Inspection Repairs

Remember all those inspection-related fixes the seller promised? Time to confirm they actually got done. Plumbing, HVAC, windows, stains from unknown origins—if it was flagged, it needs to be handled. Ask for receipts or contractor invoices. No proof = no peace of mind.

2. Ensure Personal Items Are Gone

Unless the contract says you’re inheriting the seller’s treadmill or ancient cat tree, the house should be empty. “Broom clean” does not mean “bonus boxes in the attic.” This step is part of the verification of property condition—your buyer should walk into a clean slate, not a leftover yard sale.

3. Examine the Interior – Any New Problems?

Do a full sweep for anything that wasn’t broken, dented, or mysteriously leaking the last time you saw the place. Sometimes the movers play fast and loose with doorways—and drywall. Check for:

  • New holes or scuffs
  • Damaged hardware
  • Doors or garage systems that no longer function

The goal of this final pre-closing check is to ensure the home didn’t take a beating on its way out the door. If something looks off, flag it now—because after closing, that repair bill becomes the buyer’s parting gift.

4. Examine Outdoor Areas

Don’t forget to walk the exterior. The final walk through of the house includes the backyard too. Fences suddenly falling? Moved staging pot uncovered a big hole in the deck? No one wants to discover a broken sprinkler system on move-in day—or worse, a pile of debris that didn’t make it into the moving truck.

Steps If You Find Issues During the Walkthrough

So, you’re 24 hours from closing, and the final check just revealed a fridge gone rogue or a couch-sized dent in the drywall. Now what? This is where speed and clarity matter.

Start with Clear Communication

Don’t panic—just document. Whip out your phone and start snapping photos of anything that doesn’t match the agreement. Whether it’s undone repairs, missing items, or new damage from the seller’s grand exit, you need evidence.

Then contact the listing agent right away. The faster you flag the problem, the faster the seller can fix it—or at least start groveling. Keep it factual. Notes and photos make sure everyone’s working from the same page.

Explore Options for Resolution

Depending on the issue, you’ve got a few paths forward:

  • Request Repairs: Quick fixes are possible if there’s still time—and the seller’s willing.
  • Ask for Credits or Concessions: Sometimes money off at closing is easier than scrambling to get someone in with a toolbox.
  • Bring in a Contractor: Get quotes for the damage to provide leverage for negotiations.
  • Cancel the contract: whether you can will be dependent on your agreement.

Evaluate the severity. A missing towel rack? Mildly annoying. A flooded basement? That’s gonna need more than a Home Depot run.

Delay Closing If Necessary

Major problems—like safety issues or incomplete repair work—might mean postponing the close. It’s not ideal, but better than taking ownership of a house that doesn’t meet contract terms. The goal here is to ensure the condition of the property aligns with what was promised.

Renegotiate Like a Pro

If the home’s condition doesn’t match what was agreed upon, renegotiating may be the cleanest fix. Adjust the price, ask for closing cost credits, or add a repair escrow to the deal. Go into the conversation with clear priorities—what’s a must, and what’s negotiable?

The ultimate goal? Get your buyer the home they expected without letting issues derail the entire deal. Handling this part like a boss shows you’re not just closing transactions—you’re protecting people. And in the world of final walk through real estate, that’s the difference between a frazzled agent and a trusted one.

Preparing for a Successful Final Walk Through Before Closing

The secret to a smooth walkthrough? Don’t show up empty-handed or wide-eyed. This isn’t the time for a casual stroll to “get a feel” for the place one last time. It’s your buyer’s final property condition check, and they need to walk through like they’re on a mission—because they are.

Coming in prepared helps catch missed repairs, abandoned junk, or any move-out surprises before they become your buyer’s responsibility. That’s where your trusty walkthrough checklist comes in—your personal “catch it now or regret it later” guide.

What to Bring for the Final Property Review

Heading into this last look? Pack smart. Here’s what you’ll want on hand during the pre-closing property review:

  • The purchase contract – to cross-check what was promised vs. what’s actually there
  • A notepad or mobile device – to record any “wait, what is that?” discoveries
  • A camera or phone – for photo evidence (you know, in case that fridge is mysteriously missing)
  • A flashlight – because basements and crawl spaces are never fully lit or fully innocent
  • Inspection report + receipts – to confirm every repair got done, not just “sort of handled”

Going into the final check before closing without these? That’s like showing up to a listing appointment without comps. Be thorough, be organized, and give your buyer peace of mind before they sign the dotted line.

Final Walk Through Before Closing – Why It’s the Last Line of Defense

The final walk through before closing isn’t just a formality—it’s the buyer’s last chance to make sure the home is in the agreed-upon condition. From verifying repairs to spotting last-minute surprises, we covered who attends, what to check, and how to handle issues—minus the fluff, plus a healthy dose of sarcasm. Frequently Asked Questions

What is a final walk through before closing?

A final walk through is the buyer’s last chance to ensure the home is in the agreed-upon condition before closing. It confirms repairs are complete, items are removed, and nothing new is broken.

When does the final walk through happen?

The final walk through usually happens 24 to 48 hours before closing. This gives time to resolve last-minute issues if anything’s out of place.

Who attends the final walk through?

Typically, the buyer and their real estate agent attend the final walk through. Sometimes the seller or an inspector may also be present, depending on the situation.

What should I look for during the final walk through?

During the final walk through, check that all repairs were done, personal items are removed, appliances and systems are working, and no new damage has occurred.

Can a seller refuse a final walk through?

While uncommon, a seller can technically refuse access. However, this raises red flags and may violate terms of the purchase agreement, depending on your contract and state laws.

Does the house need to be empty for the final walk through?

Yes, ideally. An empty house makes it easier to spot damage, check repairs, and ensure nothing was left behind. It also confirms the seller has vacated as agreed.

Understanding Real Estate Jokes
Practical Uses for Real Estate Jokes

Understanding Real Estate Jokes

Realtor jokes are special in their own way, often taking the hilarity from the mundane lives of real estate professionals. As with most real estate jokes, they’re the best kind of wit, based on sharp wordplay and puns, which makes them funny and illuminating. They’re widely accessible, making them perfect for real estate agents, buyers, sellers, or anyone with a basic understanding of the property market.

Their charm is in the universal appeal, making jokes about a struggle we all face, whether it’s that difficult customer or the always dreaded low commission. A perennial favorite has a buyer unable to make up his mind who says only “10% of people don’t like your carpet.” This hyperbole embodies the real fears of prospective homebuyers while eliciting some serious laughs. Much of the wit of these gags requires a second glance, rewarding the more thoughtful observers who linger on them.

What Makes Them Funny?

The best real estate jokes are based on universal themes. They play off the surprise of the market and focus on the weirdness of home showings. Wordplay and puns are the heart of their charm, needing only a little industry know-how to get the joke, not Ph.D. Level expertise.

Context is everything, as these are the kind of jokes that are most enjoyed by colleagues in the field who get the subtleties. Shared experiences amplify humor, as professionals can relate to scenarios like dealing with indecisive clients or the endless paperwork involved in transactions.

Humor in Real Estate Sales

Real estate humor can actually be a very valuable tool as a real estate sales professional, breaking the ice in client meetings or open houses and relieving tension. Second, it humanizes your brand, making it easier to build rapport with potential buyers and sellers, and creating more personable interactions.

Humorous asides can turn otherwise mundane real estate listings into page-turning thrillers. Finding that midpoint between professionalism and humor is absolutely key. The key is to keep jokes relatively tasteful and use them infrequently enough that they enhance, rather than distract from, the serious business at hand.

A light-hearted joke about how so many homes still have pink bathrooms will help you lower their guard. Additionally, it helps maintain the buzz on the sale.

Types of Real Estate Jokes

There are some real estate jokes that are just plain silly. From one-liners and puns to roasts, these jokes bring an interesting spark to conversations, leaving a lasting impression.

Here’s a closer look at the different types:

  • One-liners: Short and snappy, ideal for getting the conversation started.

Agent-specific jokes target the unique challenges agents face every day. They feature relatable situations such as stressful open houses or high-maintenance clients, creating an inside joke that bonds realtors together at industry networking mixers.

  • How many agents to screw in a light bulb? One to be on top of the bulb, seven to change the bulb, and one to take the credit. One to charge you a 1.5% commission to break even.

Quick quips are short but witty, and great for social media laughs. They nailed social media marketing and they really connect with clients.

  • Why did the realtor go to the casino? Because she heard properties were high stakes!

Engaging Real Estate Themes

Real estate themes such as open houses, mortgages, and house hunting provide a goldmine of comedic opportunities. Current trends, such as the rise of remote work, can inspire jokes about finding the perfect home office or Wi-Fi signal.

By integrating these themes into marketing strategies, whether humorously or sincerely, agencies can cut through the noise and find a relatable connection with clients. When employed creatively, these themes can help to shine a humorous light on the often-stuffy world of real estate. If designed correctly, they can be embedded into promotional marketing materials to engage and immerse audiences and encourage a fun and engaging user journey.

Lighthearted and Fun Approaches

A sense of humor is key in real estate. Playful humor also allows realtors to engage with people on an emotional level. Through the creation of clever and caring content, you’re able to ease client worries.

Simple jokes like a realtor’s prayer that we may see a tripling of GCI this year can go a long way to help lighten the mood. Authenticity is key; make sure you deliver your humor in an authentic way and it will always land better.

These strategies create a fun atmosphere while establishing trust and rapport.

Practical Uses for Real Estate Jokes

You may think that real estate jokes are a specialized hobby, but in fact they have very practical uses in the real estate business. Comedy can help defuse the atmosphere, relieve stress, break the ice, and ensure everyone feels comfortable and included.

When a client is comfortable, they are more likely to come forward with questions, allowing you to create the successful transactions they seek.

What is a Real Estate Referral?

What is a Real Estate Referral?

First off, let’s break down what a real estate referral is. In the simplest terms, a real estate referral is when you, as an agent, connect a client with another agent who’s better suited to help them. Maybe the other agent has expertise in a specific area or they’re in a different location than you?  When you refer a client to this other agent and they successfully close a deal, you earn a referral fee—usually a percentage of the commission. So, the client gets the help they need and you get a nice reward for making the agent connection. It’s a win-win for everyone involved!

Referral Example

Let me give you an example to illustrate how this works in real life. Imagine Becky, a reputable eXp real estate agent in Los Angeles. Over the years, she’s built a strong network and frequently gets inquiries from clients who are outside her service area. Becky also has a YouTube channel where she lets people know that she can help them find a realtor in all 50 states and in 24 countries.

One day, Becky gets an email from Adam, a potential client who’s looking to relocate to New York City and he wants to find an agent to help him buy a home there. Becky isn’t located in New York City but she can locate an eXp New York City agent to help Adam.

Let’s say Becky locates Mike, an eXp agent who’s a specialist in New York City. Becky reaches out to Mike, and fills him in on Adam’s situation, and Mike agrees to take on the referral in exchange for a 25% referral fee. Becky and Mike sign a referral agreement and Mike starts working with Adam. After a few weeks, Mike successfully helps Adam find the perfect home, negotiates the deal, and closes the sale.

Mike earns his commission, and in line with the agreement, Becky receives 25% of that commission as her referral fee. Not only is Adam thrilled with his new home, but Becky also enhances her reputation by connecting her client with a top-notch agent.

eXp Referral Tool

Now let’s show how easy and fast it is for eXp referral agents to make referrals using eXp Realty’s Referral Tool. The whole thing is so simple!  You have a client with a need, you find an agent, make a deal, and get paid when the deal happens.  Let’s break down those steps – everything happens in just seconds with eXp’s Referral Tool!

Finding an Agent

There are three ways to find an agent for your client:

  1. Perhaps you already know one,
  2. Perhaps someone in your sponsor line knows one, or
  3. You can search in eXp Realty’s referral tool which already connects to the eXp Agent Directory.

And, don’t forget here, that eXp Realty has over 87,000 agents around the globe so finding an eXp agent is usually pretty easy! 

  • Just hit “Select Agent” and you’ll find an agent in no time.
  • When you find an agent, call them, fill them in on the client’s needs, and agree to your referral percentage commission for a closed deal.
  • Fill out the rest of the form on the referral tool, sign the agreement and exp takes care of the rest!

Different From Other Brokerages

If you’re a referral agent at another brokerage, you know this process is either not possible because you can’t provide referrals outside your location or it involves tons of time. You need to find an agent, the hard way using the internet or, if you’re lucky, a company agent directory and then learn about the agent.  After that’s done, there’s lots more time expended. 

Like endless time to go back and forth with the agent, track down the right forms, get all the correct parties to sign the forms, collect the forms, submit those to the right place, and then follow up with the agent to see if any deal was closed and make sure you get paid what was agreed to.

eXp Realty’s Referral Tool

But with eXp Realty’s official referral tool, everything is streamlined. First, eXp’s referral tool provides an official eXp referral form that’s compliant across all U.S. states and territories. You literally have nothing to worry about or waste time thinking about.

You can easily find an agent and auto-populate the form with the receiving agent’s name and contact information.  Then you enter the other necessary details and sign the form.

Now eXp takes care of the rest.  The tool sends the agreement to all parties for eSignatures including the appropriate brokers, while shielding your client’s information until the agreement is fully signed. This ensures your client’s privacy is protected, and you’ve got a legally binding agreement in place.

After the agreement is signed, the client’s information is automatically shared with the receiving agent, and all you have to do is add your referral agreement to skyslope, sit back and wait for your referral fee to come in. eXp keeps track of it all! It’s so simple!

How to Grow a Referral Business

Now that you know how easy it is to make referrals and how lucrative it can be, let’s talk about how you can get started making referrals.  Here are some steps:

Step 1: Focus on the Referral Agent Business

This is an awesome opportunity to grow your real estate career and boost your reputation, and the best part? You don’t need extra licenses or courses to jump in. Once you’ve got your real estate license and you’re aligned with a brokerage, you can immediately start positioning yourself as a reliable referral agent. If you’re good at generating leads, this is where you can really shine.

Step 2: Build a Strong Referral Network

The quality of your referrals depends on the agents in your network, so build it wisely. Create a list of trusted agents with a proven track record of closing deals and delivering excellent service. Don’t just refer clients to friends—your reputation is at stake. Make sure the agents you’re referring to will get the job done. Keep your network organized in a spreadsheet or CRM so you can track your contacts easily.

Step 3: Find Prospects Needing Service Outside Your Area

Stay alert for opportunities when people mention relocating or needing real estate services you don’t provide. By being proactive, you can create a steady stream of referrals from those needing service outside your location or specialty.

And if you’re with eXp, you’ve got a bonus: eXp’s My Link My Lead platform. It helps you identify people in your sphere who are moving, investing, or looking for properties outside your area. It’s a game-changer for keeping tabs on potential referrals. We’ll break down that awesome platform in a future blog.

Step 4: Promote Your Referral Network

If you want to grow your referral business, you’ve got to make sure people know about it. Set aside time for events, conferences, and networking to expand your reach. Add your referral agent services to your website, business cards, social media profiles, and marketing materials.

Remind your clients—whether through newsletters or social media—that you can assist with transactions in other locations or even with different property types, like commercial real estate. Keep yourself at the top of their minds as their go-to referral resource.

Step 5: Use the Referral Tool

You’ve worked to find people who need real estate services that you can’t provide. Now just hit the link to the eXp Referral Tool and spend a few seconds to get that cash ball rolling!

There’s More

But here’s where it gets even better: eXp Realty has an actual Referral Division designed for agents who want to focus only on referral income. No MLS fees, no local board dues, no stress. You stay licensed with eXp, keep your branding, and send referrals through the official system just like every other agent—but without the day-to-day hustle of listings and buyers.

That means:

  • You can keep your license active and productive without running a traditional business
  • You still earn commission splits (typically 25%–35%) from closed deals you referred
  • You skip the typical overhead and transaction responsibilities full-service agents take on

Whether you’re semi-retired, pivoting careers, managing a side hustle, or just want to monetize your network, the eXp Referral Division is built for exactly that.
